text:
- The thing about
terrorists is if you

are scared of terrorists,
oh, they relish that, right?

If you express hatred towards
them, they feed off of that.
But if you laugh at them--
[laughter]

--I don't think they know
how to react to that.

PRIYANK MATHUR: I was
a counterterrorism

intelligence analyst
at the Department
of Homeland Security.

I also was a contributing
writer for "The Onion,"

so comedy is
something I've always
been passionate about as well.

And this idea kind of
came to me because I

know that on the surface,
comedy and counterterrorism
seem really different.

But as someone who's sort
of been involved in both,

I thought there
was an opportunity

that was there
that people weren't
really taking advantage of.

What We're doing right now
is partnering with comedians

in India, with YouTube
comedians, some of the most

popular folks on
social media here

to produce content that
counters the narrative
of terrorist groups online.

We got some proposals
for videos from a few
of the top A-list comedians.
We liked one of them the best.

This group called East India
Comedy, they had an idea

to make a video called
"I Want To Quit ISIS,"

about a young man
who works for ISIS,

realizes how ridiculously
absurd their ideology is,

and how awful life in Syria
is under them, and says,
I want to quit.

- The basic premise
was the corporatization

of the terrorism process, and
just the idea of terrorists

wearing blue shirts and
ties and going to the office

to get work done was
what the idea was--

just changing
[interposing voices]

- I had to join ISIS
for market research.
That's being cut out, for sure.

PRIYANK MATHUR: This is a risky
ask, when you ask somebody

to make a video
that criticizes ISIS
or some other terrorist group.

You know, that's a lot to ask,
because you're asking them

to put themselves out there
and put themselves potentially

in harm's way, and nobody
wants to attract the ire
of a terrorist group like ISIS.

So I wasn't sure if the
comedians were going

to go along with this,
if they were going

to be comfortable with
the fact that they'd

be making videos, essentially
paid for by the US government.

But to my surprise and delight,
they were all 100% on board
with this.

Nobody expressed any
reservations about safety.

- The first thing I told
my dad is that, guess what,

we're being funded
by the US government.

And he's like, wow, your
company's really taken off.
Well done.

Finally I'm proud
of you, my son.

PRIYANK MATHUR: The last 42
videos the State Department has

made, that were designed
to make ISIS look bad,

have gotten a combined
total of 55,000 views.

And this video that the
Indian comedians made

got 700,000 views
in just two weeks.

So I think the numbers
speak for themselves,

and that using influence or
marketing using local voices

is a much more effective
way to reach young people.
